awd_titl_txt: Lassoing Eigenvalues: A Classical and a Robust Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
The need to analyze multivariate data arises in many disciplines, including computer science, engineering, meteorology, chemometrics, psychology, sociology, biology, and genetics, among others. A primary goal of multivariate statistical analysis is to model and understand the complex interrelationships between different measurements or variables. With current trends in the sciences, an increasingly common occurrence is the collection of large amounts of information on each individual sample point or experimental unit, even though the number of sample points or experimental units themselves may remain relatively small. This results in an extremely large number of parameters or interrelationships between variables to consider, but with insufficient data to adequately model these relationships using classical statistical methods. This research project aims to investigate novel ways to model such high-dimensional data based on relatively small sample sizes. Another issue that arises when many measurements are recorded on each sample point is that of large errors or outliers in the measurements. This may make the conclusion based on classical statistical methods suspect if the outliers are not detected.  For high-dimensional data, though, detecting outliers is known to be problematic, and so an alternative is to use robust statistical methods, that is, methods producing valid conclusions even if the data contains bad data points. The robustness of the statistical methods developed within the research project will be evaluated.

This project will use penalization methods, which have a long history within statistics, for developing models and estimation procedures for high-dimensional covariance matrices. It has long been recognized that the larger and smaller sample eigenvalues of random matrices are heavily biased upwards and downwards respectively, even for moderately large sample sizes. This problem can be addressed by using penalization methods, which shrink eigenvalues together. Such shrinkage, though, cannot be accomplished using the usual penalties which are convex functions of the precision matrix. This project will employ geodesic convex penalties. Furthermore, some novel non-smooth geodesic convex penalties are to be introduced, which not only shrink eigenvalues together but also have a lasso-type effect of creating subsets of equal eigenvalues. This non-smooth penalization approach thus yields a model selection method, or more specifically a multi-spiked covariance model selection method. The geodesic convex penalization approach is to be first developed under the classical multivariate normal setting. Methods developed under this setting, though, are well known to perform poorly if the multivariate normal model does not hold.  A simple and often used approach for making classical methods more robust is the plug-in method, that is, to simply replace the role of the sample covariance matrix in a method with a robust alternative. For modest sample sizes relative to the dimension of the data, such plug-in methods tend not to differ greatly in performance from those utilizing the sample covariance matrix. To address this shortcoming, non-smooth penalized M-estimators of the covariance matrix are to be developed and studied. Here, the concept of geodesic convexity plays a crucial role.

por.por_cntn:
This research project developed new estimators for the covariance matrix, which is a fundamental concept underlying most statistical procedures used for analyzing multidimensional data. The covariance matrix contains essential information on the relationships and interactions between measured variables. The need to analyze multidimensional data arises in many diverse disciplines, such as computer science, psychology, meteorology, chemometrics, sociology, biology and engineering.

Two features of modern data collection often make the classical estimates of the covariance matrix inappropriate. First, robustness concerns, namely data arising in many disciplines can often be messy in that they can be subject to numerous outliers or errors not accounted for by any model. Such outliers are known to be extremely difficult to detect in the multidimensional setting. This can result in data analysis based on classical estimates of the covariance matrix being unreliable. Second, sparsity concerns, these arise since an increasingly common occurrence due to current trends in science is that a large amount of information is often collected on each subject or study unit. This results in an extremely large number of covariance parameters needing to be estimated relative to the sample size. Consequently, the resulting statistical analysis lacks precision and is more heavily dependent on chance, i.e. on the statistical vari- ability of the measurements.

The supported research is among the first to introduce new statistical methodology which address both of the above-mentioned concerns and which alleviates some of the data analysis shortcomings they cause. The significant results arising from this research project are primarily of a theoretical/mathematical na- ture. These include the use of M-estimators for addressing the robustness concerns together with the use of penalization methods for addressing the sparsity concerns. In this research, a novel application of the geodesic convexity, a concept which is not widely known within the field of statistics, plays a central role in the development of the new multivariate statistical methodology. This concept is used to produce ele- gant mathematical proofs for the theory underlying the new methodology as well as in the development of proven computational algorithms for these methods. The theoretical approaches developed in this research project provide a foundation upon which other researchers in the field can build. The results of this research have been published in some of the top journals in the field of statistics, and have also been disseminated via some invited and keynote talks at international conferences.

The PI anticipates the new methodology may eventually become adopted within the various disci- plines which deal with multidimensional data and become part of their standard methodology. This research project gave special consideration to applications within Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE). The PI has interacted extensively with researchers within ECE, and in particular within the sub- area of signal processing, wherein there is a strong interest in robust methods for multidimensional data. This interaction/collaboration has a twofold beneficial impact. First, it exposes the PI to practical issues arising in applied areas and to the approaches used therein to address these issues. Second, the PI is able to bring a strong statistical background and a deep knowledge of robustness and multivariate statistics to researchers in ECE, which can be valuable for efficiently addressing these statistical issues in their field.

This research project provided partial support for a doctoral student within the Department of Statis- tics at Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey, who successful defended her doctoral dissertation in 2019 with the PI serving as her advisor. Her dissertation was based on topics arising from this research project. After her PhD, she first held a post-doctoral fellowship at a leading international university and is currently an assistant professor. She has since authored several other publications independent of the PI. Although not supported by this grant, the PI has worked closely and mentored a doctoral student in ECE, who recently completed his PhD at a leading international university, and have published joint scientific papers together on topics related to this research projects. Finally, some of the results of the project, in particular the results on the role of geodesic convexity in multivariate statistics, have been incorporated into the PI’s doctoral level course on theoretical multivariate analysis.
